issue.title: Support dynamic tests

repository.name: quickperf
repository.description: QuickPerf is a testing library for Java to quickly evaluate and improve some performance-related properties

issue.body:
It didn't support JVM annotations yet as we cannot fork the VM due to https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2399

PerformanceReport are done per dynamic test but annotation declaration are per test factory method so the same annotation will be used by all dynamic test provided by a test factory method. This needs to be taken into account when creating multiple dynamic tests on a single test factory method.

When merged, I'll provide an example application.
Documentation will also need to be updated.

body:
You can intercept the `@TestFactory` method by overriding `interceptTestFactoryMethod(...)`. The `ExtensionContext` provided to `interceptDynamicTest(...)` contains the information about the `DynamicTest`, e.g. its name. You could use the `ExtensionContext` as well for traversing up the hierarchy to find the `ExtensionContext` of the `@TestFactory` method.

@loicmathieu Does that help? What's your exact use case?
How do you transfer the `Executable` to a different VM? Couldn't you do the same with the `Invocation`?

When intercepting a test method, I use the `ReflectiveInvocationContext<Method>` to access the Method and I directly invoke it.

When intercepting a dynamic test method, I would need the Executable to do something similar.

It's not very convenient for us as we want to directly invoke the test method because our test framewok make some low level stuff. For example we have the ability to measure the allocation of a test method, to lower the interraction between the test method and the test framework we fork the JVM and directly invoke the test method inside the forked VM.

This is how it works for JUnit4, TestNG and JUnit5 test methods.
This is how we want to make it work for Dynamic tests.
Tentatively slated for 5.8 M1 solely for the purpose of _team discussion_.

rename.from: InvocationInterceptor.interceptDynamicTest don't give access to the invocation context
rename.to: InvocationInterceptor.interceptDynamicTest does not provide access to the invocation context

body:
Hi, is this considered for inclusion ?

I create an example implementation by passing the `Executable` to the interceptor: https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/compare/main...loicmathieu:feat/access-dynamic-test-executable

Of course this is only a proposal implementation to show how it can work. As it would break the existing interceptors maybe it needs to keep the old method for backward compability.

**Team decision:** Add an overload of `interceptDynamicTest` that takes an `Invocation<Void>`, a `DynamicTestInvocationContext`, and an `ExtensionContext` that delegates to the old `interceptDynamicTest` method (so that existing extensions still work), and deprecate the old method. `DynamicTestInvocationContext` will just have a single method (for now): `Executable getExecutable()`.

@loicmathieu Thanks for the initial spike! Would you like to work on a PR?
@marcphilipp great! I'll be happy to work on a PR for it.

issue.title: Expose DynamicTest executable to InvocationInterceptors

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Allow dynamic test invocation interceptors to access the dynamic test executable.

Fixes #2399

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass
